newsitem.title: USA: Magellan betting on airline, tech stocks - analysts.
newsitem.headline: Magellan betting on airline, tech stocks - analysts.

text.p: Fidelity Investments behemoth Magellan Fund has been stocking up on big names in the airline, technology, healthcare and retail sectors, even as the overall U.S. stock market has taken a beating in recent weeks, according to Fidelity watchers.

"The strongest sector has been air transport," said David O'Leary, president of Alpha Equity Research, of Portsmouth, N.H., which tracks Fidelity activity. "We've picked up signals that (Magellan) is continuing to buy technology, healthcare and retail."
Robert Stansky, portfolio manager of Magellan, the largest fund in the United States, has been buying UAL Corp, Delta Air Lines, AMR Corp and Continental Airlines Inc, according to O'Leary.
Stansky has also made bets on Microsoft Corp, Intel Corp, Dell Computer Corp, and Cisco Systems Inc.
Between February and April, the S&P 500 index has declined about eight percent, and the drop in some technology issues has been even sharper.
Among retail stocks, Stansky has bought Wal-Mart Stores Inc, Home Depot Inc, and Lowe's Cos Inc, according to O'Leary.
Recent healthcare purchases include Warner-Lambert Co, and Bristol-Myers Squibb Co, as well as Oxford Health Plans Inc and Healthsouth Corp, O'Leary added.

Analysts said the buying spree was consistent with Stansky's long-time devotion to growth stocks. "He's certainly looking for accelerated earnings growth," said Eric Kobren, president of the Fidelity Insight newsletter.
Analysts said the asset allocation changes indicate that Stansky is committed to fully investing the fund in stocks.
"I don't think there's been much of a change in the strategy," said Eric Kobren, president of Fidelity Insight.
Some analysts criticized Stansky for taking a long time to get rid of the bond holdings. "I'm shocked at how slowly he reacted," said O'Leary. "Very slowly, like a tortoise."
But they acknowledged that the transition was complicated because he needed to find stocks to buy with the cash from sale of the bonds.
Analysts said that while Stansky has steered the fund to growth stocks, investors continued to pull their money out in large chunks -- though at a slower rate.
Kobren estimated that Magellan had net redemptions of $540 million in March compared to $1.2 billion in January redemptions.
O'Leary estimated investors have taken $9 billion out of the fund since Stansky took over last June.
Magellan's net assets dropped to $51.42 billion at March 31 compared to $53.79 billion at February 28.
